across.text: Abolish hotel by river where people go to eat
across.explanation: CHOPHOUSE(i.e. “where people go to eat”). Solution is CHOP (i.e. “abolish”) followed by H (“hotel” in the phonetic alphabet) and OUSE (i.e. a “river”).

across.text: Mineral from drinking goblet, not one put on back of lorry
across.explanation: CHALCEDONY(i.e. “mineral”). Solution is CHALICE (i.e. “drinking goblet”) with the I removed (indicated by “not [Roman numeral] one”) and the remainder followed by DON (i.e. “put on”) and Y (i.e. “back of lorry”, i.e. the last letter of “lorry”), like so: CHALCE-DON-Y. One gotten mostly through the wordplay.

across.text: Notorious gangster’s problem casing Yankee plant
across.explanation: ALYSSUM(i.e. “plant”). Solution is AL’S SUM (i.e. “notorious gangster’s problem” – AL being Al Capone, and SUM being “a problem in addition, or in arithmetic generally”(Chambers)) wrapped around or “carrying” Y (“Yankee” in the phonetic alphabet), like so: AL(Y)’S-SUM.

across.text: Quirky fellow ringing about money
across.explanation: ECCENTRIC(i.e. “quirky”). Solution is ERIC (i.e. “fellow”, basically a man’s name) wrapped around or “ringing” C (i.e. “about”, specifically a recognised abbreviation of “circa”) and CENT (i.e. “money”), like so: E(C-CENT)RIC.

across.text: Absolutely what an author would do for listeners
across.explanation: RIGHT(i.e. “absolutely” – both can be used to express agreement). “For listeners” indicates homophone. Solution is a homophone of WRITE (i.e. “what an author would do”).

across.text: Bug eerie E Sussex town picked up
across.explanation: CREEPY-CRAWLY(i.e. “bug”). Solution is CREEPY (i.e. “eerie”) followed by a homophone (indicated by “picked up”) of CRAWLEY (i.e. “E Sussex town”).

across.text: Girl Ted clobbered with whip: it prevents stock going missing!
across.explanation: CATTLE-GRID(i.e. “it prevents [live]stock going missing”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “clobbered”) of GIRL TED placed after or “with” CAT (i.e. “whip”, specifically a cat-o-nine-tails), like so: CAT-TLEGRID.

across.text: Tree left by old poet in my part of London
across.explanation: LOMBARDY POPLAR(i.e. “tree”). Solution is L (a recognised abbreviation of “left”) followed by O (ditto “old”), then BARD (i.e. “poet”) once placed “in” MY. The whole is then followed by POPLAR (i.e. “part of London”), like so: L-O-M(BARD)Y-POPLAR.

across.text: Absent-minded detective’s distinguishing feature
across.explanation: DISTRAIT(i.e. “absent-minded”). Solution is DI’S (i.e. “detective’s”, specifically a Detective Inspector) followed by TRAIT (i.e. “distinguishing feature”).

across.text: Powder used in hospital (Cumbrian)
across.explanation: TALCUM(i.e. “powder”). “In” indicates the solution has been hidden in the clue, like so: HOSPI(TAL CUM)BRIAN.

across.text: Her music so confused some of the singers
across.explanation: SEMICHORUS(i.e. “some of the singers”). “Confused” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of HER MUSIC SO.[EDIT – Thanks to several commenters for flagging a typo in this one. I’d written SEMICHORAL for some reason. Cheers, all! – LP]

across.text: Notice girl dropping by spontaneously
across.explanation: AD-LIB(i.e. “spontaneously”). Solution is AD (i.e. “notice”, i.e. a shortened form of “advertisement”) followed by LIBBY (i.e. “girl”, basically a girl’s name) once the BY has been removed (indicated by “dropping by”).

across.text: Bloomin’ tailless fish!
across.explanation: RUDD(i.e. “fish”). Solution is RUDDY (i.e. “bloomin’”, both minor oaths) with its last letter removed (indicated by “tailless”).

across.text: Agreement worker associated with enchanting female group
across.explanation: COVENANT(i.e. “agreement”). Solution is ANT (i.e. “worker”) placed after or “with” COVEN (i.e. “enchanting female group”), like so: COVEN-ANT.

across.text: People engaged by board, not impossible to find
across.explanation: TRACEABLE(i.e. “not impossible to find”). Solution is RACE (i.e. “people”) placed in or “engaged by” TABLE (i.e. “board”, the table company bigwigs sit around), like so: T(RACE)ABLE.

across.text: Silver-tongued Conservative leaving badly organised public sale
across.explanation: PLAUSIBLE(i.e. “silver-tongued”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “badly organised”) of PUBLIC SALE once the C has been removed (indicated by “Conservative leaving” – C being a recognised abbreviation of “Conservative”).

across.text: Free novel initially enjoyed by fashionable young man
across.explanation: BUCKSHEE(i.e. “free” or gratuitous). Solution is SHE (i.e. “novel” by H. Rider Haggard) and E (i.e. “initially enjoyed”, i.e. the first letter of “enjoyed”) both placed after or “by” BUCK (i.e. “fashionable young man”), like so: BUCK-SHE-E.

across.text: Actors in musical with Eliot in a spin
across.explanation: CAST(i.e. “actors”). Solution is CATS (i.e. “musical”) with the TS (i.e. “Eliot”, the poet) reversed (indicated by “in a spin”), like so: CA(TS) => CA(ST).

across.text: Cricket side everyone backs, it’s plain
across.explanation: LLANO(i.e. South American “plain”). Solution is ON (i.e. “cricket side”, sometimes called leg side) and ALL (i.e. “everyone”) all reversed (indicated by “backs”), like so: LLA-NO.

across.text: Enclosure ultimately very analytic, not in papal letter
across.explanation: ENCYCLICAL(i.e. “papal letter” sent by the Pope to all his bishops). Solution is ENC (a recognised abbreviation of “enclosure” used in formal correspondence) followed by Y (i.e. “ultimately very”, i.e. the last letter of “very”) and CLINICAL (i.e. “analytic”) with the IN removed (indicated by “not in”), like so: ENC-Y-CLICAL.

across.text: Muslim official once – namely one employed by Queen
across.explanation: VIZIER(i.e. “Muslim official once”). Solution is VIZ (i.e. “namely”, a shortened form of the Latinvidelicet) followed by I (i.e. “[Roman numeral] one”) and ER (i.e. “Queen”, specifically Elizabeth Regina).

across.text: Vehicles carrying lean Spanish monarchists
across.explanation: CARLISTS(i.e. “Spanish monarchists”). Solution is CARS (i.e. “vehicles”) wrapped around or “carrying” LIST (i.e. “lean”), like so: CAR(LIST)S.

across.text: S Atlantic islands transformed by Canadian with thrust
across.explanation: TRISTAN DA CUNHA(i.e. “S Atlantic islands”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “transformed”) of CANADIAN and THRUST.

across.text: Naval officer unexpectedly hid maps in entrance to mess
across.explanation: MIDSHIPMAN(i.e. “naval officer”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “unexpectedly”) of HID MAPS IN and M (i.e. “entrance to mess”, i.e. the first letter of “mess”).Pro tip: setters sometimes like to refer to EASY as “midshipman”, after the 1836 novelMr Midshipman Easyby Frederick Marryat, which we have obviously all read.

across.text: Singer or priest turning over unfinished sculpture
across.explanation: BASSO-RELIEVO(i.e. “sculpture”, also known as a bas-relief). Solution is BASS (i.e. “singer”) followed by OR, then ELI (i.e. “priest” – a favourite wordplay of several setters) and OVER once its last letter has been removed (indicated by “unfinished”) and the remainder reversed (indicated by “turning”), like so: BASS-OR-ELI-EVO.

across.text: Container brought back by soldiers for gunpowder constituent
across.explanation: NITRE(i.e. “gunpowder constituent”). Solution is TIN (i.e. “container”) reversed (indicated by “brought back”) and followed by RE (i.e. “soldiers”, specifically the Royal Engineers of the British Army), like so: NIT-RE.

across.text: Adverse info about old times dishonestly come by
across.explanation: ILL-GOTTEN(i.e. “dishonestly come by”). Solution is ILL (i.e. “adverse”) followed by GEN (i.e. “info”) once wrapped “about” O (a recognised abbreviation of “old”) and TT (i.e. “times” – T is a recognised abbreviation of “time”, two Ts gets you “times”), like so: ILL-G(O-TT)EN.

across.text: Weighty matter party goes over after all the others
across.explanation: BALLAST(i.e. “weighty matter”). Solution is LAB (i.e. “party”, specifically a shortened form of the Labour Party) reversed (indicated by “goes over”) and followed by LAST (i.e. “after all the others”), like so: BAL-LAST.

across.text: European left visitor briefly in posh quarter
across.explanation: PORTUGUESE(i.e. “European”). Solution is PORT (i.e. “left” side of a ship) followed by GUEST (i.e. “visitor”) once its last letter has been removed (indicated by “briefly”) and the remainder placed between U (a recognised abbreviation of the upper class, or “posh” lot) and E (i.e. one “quarter” of a compass, being a recognised abbreviation of “east”), like so: PORT-U-(GUES)-E.

across.text: Roofing requirement I’d obtain in anger
across.explanation: RIDGE TILE(i.e. “roofing requirement”). Solution is I’D and GET (i.e. “obtain”) both placed “in” RILE (i.e. “anger”), like so: R(I’D-GET)ILE.

down.text: Wife leaves old Welsh county, going over English river
down.explanation: CLYDE(i.e. “river”). Solution is CLWYD (i.e. “old Welsh county”) with the W removed (indicated by “wife leaves” – W being a recognised abbreviation of “wife”) and the remainder followed by E (a recognised abbreviation of “English”), like so: CLYD-E.

down.text: Old French art work capturing witch’s gullet
down.explanation: OESOPHAGUS(i.e. “gullet”). Solution is O (a recognised abbreviation of “old”) followed by ES (i.e. “French art” – we’ve seen this one recently, being the French for “are”, or “art” in ye olde times), then OPUS (i.e. “work”) once wrapped around or “capturing” HAG (i.e. “witch”), like so: O-ES-OP(HAG)US.

down.text: Murderer – one detectives found in private residence
down.explanation: HOMICIDE(i.e. “murderer” – can refer to the criminal as well as the crime). Solution is I (i.e. “[Roman numeral] one”) and CID (i.e. “detectives”, specifically the Criminal Investigation Department) both placed “in” HOME (i.e. “private residence”), like so: HOM(I-CID)E.

down.text: Schedule mainly involves this group of Muslim scholars
down.explanation: ULEMA(i.e. “group of Muslim scholars”). “Involves” indicates the solution is hidden in the clue, like so: SCHED(ULE MA)INLY.

down.text: Oil producers having typical ground south of Brussels
down.explanation: EUCALYPTI(i.e. “oil producers”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “ground”) of TYPICAL placed after or “south of” – this being a down clue – EU (i.e. “Brussels”, seat of the European Union), like so: EU-CALYPTI.

down.text: Attorney leaves Commonwealth country for scene of marriage feast
down.explanation: CANA(i.e. “scene of marriage feast” at which Jesus was said to have turned water into wine). Solution is CANADA (i.e. “Commonwealth country”) with the DA removed (indicated by “attorney leaves” – DA being a District Attorney).

down.text: Abroad securing Irish transport route
down.explanation: AIRWAY(i.e. “transport route”). Solution is AWAY (i.e. “abroad”) wrapped around or “securing” IR (a recognised abbreviation of “Irish”), like so: A(IR)WAY.

down.text: Publican aid’s creating agitation in Manhattan?
down.explanation: COCKTAIL SHAKER(i.e. “publican’s aid”). Clue plays on Manhattan being a cocktail. You get the idea.

down.text: Extremely weird new retreat oddly, a Cumbrian lake
down.explanation: DERWENTWATER(i.e. “a Cumbrian lake”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “oddly”) of WD (i.e. “extremely weird”, i.e. the first and last letters of “weird”) and NEW RETREAT.

down.text: Rise of first-class fellow in W African republic
down.explanation: NIGERIA(i.e. “W African republic”). Solution is AI (i.e. “first-class”, i.e. A1 with I representing the 1 – a favourite play of several setters) followed by REG (i.e. “fellow”, basically a man’s name) and IN, all reversed (indicated by “rise of” – this being a down clue), like so: NI-GER-IA.

down.text: Electronic device a local court deployed, missing nothing
down.explanation: CALCULATOR(i.e. “electronic device”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “deployed”) of A LOCAL COURT once one of the Os has been removed (indicated by “missing nothing”).

down.text: Returning, amend story about book constituting navigational aid
down.explanation: TIDE TABLE(i.e. “navigational aid”). Solution is EDIT (i.e. “amend”) reversed (indicated by “returning”) and followed by TALE (i.e. “story”) once wrapped “about” B (a recognised abbreviation of “book”), like so: TIDE-TA(B)LE.

down.text: Pitiful way to get quote set up!
down.explanation: PATHETIC(i.e. “pitiful”). Solution is PATH (i.e. “way”) followed by CITE (i.e. “quote”) reversed (indicated by “set up” – this being a down clue), like so: PATH-ETIC.

down.text: Genial sounding, taking small drink before a production
down.explanation: MELODRAMA(i.e. “production”). Solution is a homophone (indicated by “sounding”) of MELLOW (i.e. “genial”) followed by DRAM (i.e. “small drink”) and A, like so: MELO-DRAM-A.

down.text: First choice when low-value coins secure advert
down.explanation: PREFERENCE(i.e. “first choice”). Solution is PENCE (i.e. “low value coins”) wrapped around or “securing” REFER (i.e. “advert” – a variant meaning of the word, from the Latinadvertere), like so: P(REFER)ENCE.

down.text: Capital invested at first in unruly kid’s discharge
down.explanation: BRATISLAVA(i.e. “capital” of Slovakia). Solution is I (i.e. “invested at first”, i.e. the first letter of “invested”) placed “in” BRAT’S (i.e. “unruly kid’s”) and followed by LAVA (i.e. volcanic “discharge”), like so: BRAT(I)’S-LAVA.

down.text: Politician, Republican, heretic – one looking after books
down.explanation: LIBRARIAN(i.e. “one looking after books”). Solution is LIB (i.e. “politician”, specifically a shortened form of Liberal) followed by R (ditto “Republican”) and ARIAN (i.e. “heretic”, specifically a follower of Arius who believed Christ was not the son of God but the first and highest of mortals).

down.text: Drink putting an end to string player’s technique
down.explanation: DOUBLE-STOPPING(i.e. “string player’s technique” – arecent repeat). Solution is DOUBLE (i.e. a measure of “drink”) followed by STOPPING (i.e. “putting an end to”).

down.text: A pound bill (or more, ultimately) for fish
down.explanation: ALBACORE(i.e. “fish”). Solution is A followed by LB (a recognised abbreviation of “pound” weight, after the Latinlibra), then AC (i.e. “bill”, specifically a recognised abbreviation of “account”), then OR and E (i.e. “more, ultimately”, i.e. the last letter of “more”).

down.text: Disbelief as regarding one’s Queen visiting shelter
down.explanation: ASTONISHMENT(i.e. “disbelief”). Solution is AS followed by ON (i.e. “regarding”), I’S (i.e. “[Roman numeral] one’s”) and HM (i.e. “Queen”, specifically a recognised abbreviation of Her Majesty) once all placed in or “visiting” TENT (i.e. “shelter”), like so: AS-T(ON-I’S-HM)ENT.

down.text: Law enforcer’s plan of action endlessly upset celebrity
down.explanation: POLICEMAN(i.e. “law enforcer”). Solution is POLICY (i.e. “plan of action”) with its last letter removed (indicated by “endlessly”) and the remainder followed by NAME (i.e. “celebrity”) once reversed (indicated by “upset” – this being a down clue), like so: POLIC-EMAN.

down.text: Tat a rector recycled, making sculpture perhaps
down.explanation: TERRACOTTA(i.e. “sculpture perhaps”). “Recycled” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of TAT A RECTOR.

down.text: Cull a flower, so to speak – it adds zest to the course
down.explanation: PICCALILLI(i.e. “it adds zest to the course” or meal. Well, it would if it wasn’t always the jar left unopened from a Christmas hamper). “So to speak” indicates homophone. Solution is a homophone of PICK A LILY (i.e. “cull a flower” – to cull is to select or “pick” out for destruction).

down.text: Fellow required in Bury right away
down.explanation: INSTANTER(i.e. “right away” in legalese). Solution is STAN (i.e. “fellow”, basically a man’s name) placed “in” INTER (i.e. “bury” – ignore the misleading capitalisation), like so: IN(STAN)TER.

down.text: Clever, accepting woman as deserving love
down.explanation: ADORABLE(i.e. “deserving love”). Solution is ABLE (i.e. “clever”) wrapped around or “accepting” DORA (i.e. “woman” – a lot of people’s names in this one, isn’t there?), like so: A(DORA)BLE.

down.text: Delivered books primarily telling of 18th-cent masquerade
down.explanation: RIDOTTO(i.e. “18th-cent masquerade”). Solution is RID (i.e. “delivered”) followed by OT (i.e. “books”, specifically the Old Testament of The Bible) and TO (i.e. “primarily telling of”, i.e. the first letters of “telling” and “of”). One gotten from a combination of the wordplay and a decent thumbing of my Bradford’s and Chambers.

down.text: Scottish magistrate, that is, propping up cricketers’ bar?
down.explanation: BAILIE(i.e. “Scottish magistrate”). Solution is IE (i.e. “that is”, i.e. …um… “i.e.”!) placed after or “propping up” – this being a down clue – BAIL (i.e. a “cricketers’ bar” that sits atop the stumps), like so: BAIL-IE.

down.text: Academics upset about conclusion of priestly council
down.explanation: SYNOD(i.e. “council”). Solution is DONS (i.e. “academics”) reversed (indicated by “upset” – this being a down clue) and wrapped “about” Y (i.e. “conclusion of priestly”, i.e. the last letter of “priestly”), like so: S(Y)NOD.

down.text: DeleteTimeseditorial for a start
down.explanation: ERASE(i.e. “delete”). Solution is ERAS (i.e. “times” – ignore the misleading capitalisation) followed by E (i.e. “editorial for a start”, i.e. the first letter of “editorial”).

down.text: Sleep lightly, being nearly twelve
down.explanation: DOZE(i.e. “sleep lightly”). Solution is DOZEN (i.e. “twelve”) with its last letter removed (indicated by “nearly”).
